title: Who are the favourites for the 2023 Vuelta a España?
content:
Cyclist
Who are the favourites for the 2023 Vuelta a España?

The 2023 Vuelta a España starts on Saturday 26th August and looks like it could be the most exciting Grand Tour for a long time. With an incredibly difficult route that including monstrous climbs of the Col du Tourmalet and Alto de l’Angliru, there’ll be plenty to separate the main contenders early on.

Not only that, but the start list is completely stacked with riders who could challenge for the overall winner’s red jersey, the only notable absence being Tadej Pogačar, who’s taking the time to rest before undoubtedly sweeping the Italian classics for a third time.

Yes, that does mean that two-time Tour de France winner Jonas Vingegaard is attempting to become the first man since Chris Froome to do the Tour-Vuelta double and he’ll be joined on the Jumbo-Visma team by three-time Vuelta winner Primož Roglič, who’s attempting to be the first man to do the Giro-Vuelta double since Alberto Contador. However, will they have equal backing? Only time will tell.

The riders hoping to prevent Jumbo-Visma from becoming the first team ever to win all three men’s Grand Tours in a single season include defending champion Remco Evenepoel of Soudal-QuickStep, Tadej Pogačar’s UAE Team Emirates teammate and Spain’s own super-talent Juan Ayuso, and one of Ineos Grenadiers’ former Tour de France winners Geraint Thomas.

Related Posts

Is it time to swap the dates of the Giro and Vuelta?

The Vuelta a España leader’s red jersey: Everything you need to know

Vuelta a España 2023: Stage-by-stage preview and everything we know so far

Jonas Vingegaard, Jumbo Visma

The last time a Tour de France winner even rode the Vuelta in the same season was Chris Froome in 2017, when he won both, so no pressure on Jonas Vingegaard then. The Dane hasn’t raced since the Tour de France, avoiding the World Championships to keep his shape for the Vuelta. There will be less pressure on him than in France because of Jumbo-Visma’s two-leader approach, but Vingegaard will be expected to play a big part in securing the Grand Tour Grand Slam. If he’s even near to his Tour de France form no one will come close.

Rating: 4.5/5

Primož Roglič, Jumbo-Visma

Mr Vuelta himself Primož Roglič is back to try to win his fourth red jersey after Remco Evenepoel (with help from Fred Wright) usurped him last year. He left it late to win the Giro earlier in the year, looking pretty normal until the final mountain time-trial, but that win plus a very quiet summer – his only race since the Giro was the Vuelta a Burgos last week, which he won – should put him in good stead to come in hot. Unfortunately for him, Roglič’s biggest challenger is his teammate and it wouldn’t be surprising if he’s working for VIngegaard come the third week. If that happens, cue Ineos transfer rumours.

Rating: 4/5

Remco Evenepoel, Soudal-QuickStep

Last year’s winner Remco Evenepoel is looking to make up for dropping out of the Giro while in the race lead having tested positive for Covid-19. With Vingegaard joining Roglič in the race, this will be Evenepoel’s biggest Grand Tour test, if he comes out on top then he’ll be firmly on the cusp on joining Vingegaard and Pogačar in the top tier of contenders. However, with heightened pressure on his Soudal-QuickStep team to support his general classification ambitions and hardly the strongest line-up to assist him, questions will be asked if he’s left to fend for himself and loses. If that happens, cue Ineos tranfer rumours.

Rating: 4/5

Juan Ayuso, UAE Team Emirates

20-year-old Juan Ayuso has only ridden one Grand Tour in his career, coming third in the Vuelta last year. He’s the next in line to the young super-talent throne that Evenepoel currently holds after Tadej Pogačar got old. The quality of the field here puts him in a tough position to improve on his 2022 result, however with his continuing development, it wouldn’t be a surprise to see a proper breakthrough this time around. He’s likely to become the first Spaniard to win a Grand Tour since Alberto Contador at the 2015 Giro, but it probably won’t be here.

Rating: 3/5

Geraint Thomas, Ineos Grenadiers

Geraint Thomas came so close to winning the Giro that it can’t have been easy to get over that and turn his attention to the Vuelta but that’s what he did. The only races he’s done since is a roll-out at the Tour de Pologne and tenth in the World Championships time-trial, so who knows what kind of form he’s actually in. Thomas has only ridden the Vuelta once before, finishing 69th overall in 2015, when he was a mountain domestique and Classics rider, so this is new territory. Don’t expect a win, but don’t be surprised if he completes his set of Grand Tour podiums. How differently would we be talking if that one Giro stage went differently?

Rating: 3/5

Outsiders

Given the sheer number of top level contenders, there aren’t many others that will be looking to challenge the general classification, but there are a few riders looking to give the apple cart a mental breakdown as well as a few climbers who could use a breakaway to get into contention and a few young riders looking to break through.

Keep an eye out for: Enric Mas (Movistar), João Almeida (UAE Team Emirates), Thymen Arensman (Ineos Grenadiers), Romain Bardet, Oscar Onley, Max Poole (all DSM-Firmenich), Damiano Caruso, Mikel Landa (both Bahrain Victorious), Eddie Dunbar (Jayco-AlUla), Lenny Martinez, Romain Gregoire (both Groupama-FDJ), Juan Pedro López (Lidl-Trek), Hugh Carthy (EF Education-EasyPost), Cian Uijtdebroeks, Aleksandr Vlasov, Sergio Higuita (all Bora-Hansgrohe).

The Cyclist prediction

After hyping up the most open and exciting Grand Tour ever, Jumbo-Visma will take the red jersey in the opening stage team time-trial, Jan Tratnik will pass the jersey to Vingegaard on the first mountain stage – Stage 3! – and the Dane will take it all the way to Madrid. Boooring…

The post Who are the favourites for the 2023 Vuelta a España? appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
